Article: Anyone who has lived through the media-world turmoil of the last two decades knows that âreinventionâ is the only survival skill remaining to just about every newsroomÂ â whether a general-interest newspaper or a trade publication. By both necessity and second nature, we adapt to changes. We work with fewer colleagues, figure out new ways to tell stories and learn, on the fly, to be fluent in new media (i.e. print, Special Projects and podcasts). Itâs no secret that our newsroom at Aspencore Media recently lost a few of our top-notch reporters. Just as this sort of all-too-frequent development upsets our audience in the electronics industry, it is equally devastating to those of us who remain. After all, they werenât just our colleagues; they were dear friends with whom we grew up at EE Times and other publications now owned by Aspencore Media. Every day across years we shared sources and contact information, traded war stories, laughed and bellyached. In this light, we understand the concerns expressed in the many phone calls, emails and personal messages from you in the electronics industryÂ â asking us point-blank: Is EE Times getting shut down? The point-blank answer is no . Far from it. According to my partner in crime, Bolaji Ojo, Aspencore’s Global editor-in-chief and general manager of EMEA, “The reality is that the network of editors, correspondents and contributors serving our readers has actually increased over the course of the last year. Way before the recent downsizing, EE Times and Aspencore had been expanding the team, adding critical experts as full-time employees, regular freelance contributors and analysts.” He explained, “Each of the people who have joined as contributors to the Aspencore network in the last year brings a specific range of critical expertise needed to provide the full breadth of coverage the industry requires. We have added experts in the fields of AI, IoT, sensors, power, interconnects, passives and electromechanical (IP&E) components, distribution and supply chain. Name the industry segment and we have it covered. If we don’t have certain experts currently, you can bet that we are hunting for them.” That’s because the landscape is changing for our readers, customers and other observers. As the market has evolved, so has the Aspencore network. Bolaji stressed, “Beyond the industry experts added, we have also expanded our coverage deeper into all regions to reflect the diversity in terms of where design engineering, components development and market growth are taking place. The stories filed by Aspencore editors and other contributors reflect local relevance where appropriate but they are also flavored with global context. It’s a global market, afterall. But we don’t just send editors from North America to cover Europe and Asia. Aspencore has editors and reporters in these regions and they collaborate with colleagues all over the world.” Who we are Over the last twenty years, the owners and management of our newsroom have changed (too) many times. But weâre proud to say that EE Times has a very resilient newsroom. Our editors have spines of solid brass. We remain the independent voice of the global electronics industry. We wonât suggest that these are not hard times. But we also wonât dissemble about our firm commitment to blazing a path forward. In a nutshell, our answer to the current newsroom upheaval is to go global, whole hog.  As noted, among all publications covering the global electronics industry, we are proud to say that we are the only game in town. We boast more than 30 editors for EE Times and other vertical publications owned by Aspencore Media. They are scattered all over the world â from Shenzhen and Beijing to Taipei, London, Paris, Bern, Milan and Portland, San Jose, Washington, Massachusetts, Arizona and even Madison, Wisconsin. Some are full-time and others are part-time contributing editors. We also have a stable of young, passionate and eager-to-learn reporters. Iâm sometimes amazed at the range of our newsroomÂ â both in its depth and breadth. Our newsroom has evolved in its capacity to cover and analyze whatâs happening in the electronics industryÂ â throughout the world. Furthermore, we’ve broken out of our regional silos. Our global newsroom is constantly exchanging story ideas. We are translating, more often than before, relevant stories posted by our Asian colleaguesÂ â from Chinese to English. Sometimes, our U.S. or London team picks up where our Asian colleagues left off as they advance important stories. As Richard Wallace, former editorial director of EE Times , used to tell us, the EE Times newsroom has always understood that it isnât just Silicon Valley: âThe world is our oyster.â Brian Fuller, former editor-in-chief of EE Times , wrote to me a few weeks ago: âMy two cents: EE Times is the last independent voice in the industry, even though itâs owned by Aspencore. It is not pay-to-play which makes it that last of a breed. Everyone else (no matter how much they say they arenât) are pay to play â¦ Companies hated negative press in EE Times , but they LOVED and lived on good coverage when it was merited. It was unmatched validation.â As another industry executive wrote to me, âWe need reporting on what is happening in our industry, now more than ever!â Our promise to you is that we remain that independent voice of the global electronics industry. Our newsroom stands on the shoulders of great publishers and editors in the past, including Girish Mhatre, Steve Weitzner and Richard Wallace. Under them, we learned to be a tag-team of tenacious newshounds with (to cite Lou Grant) spunk. In the following pages, weâll be introducing our newsroom today â all of us. Just as the electronics industry has truly gone global, so have we. We intend to continue working closely with you in the electronics industry. Give us a call, ping us, donât hesitate to get directly in touch with our global team â any time of day. After all, with editors in almost every time zone on earth, the sun never sets on EE Times .
